lesson.name: Lesson 1.13 Teacher Guide: Writing Equations of Parallel and Perpendicular Lines

page.title: 1.13.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students continue to examine methods of writing an equation of a line. While exploring the new topic, students will review finding slope and writing lines in point-slope and slope-intercept form. They also use their understanding of the \(y\)-intercept form of the equation of a line. In recent lessons, students learned that the method they use to write the equation of a line is determined by the information given. They will continue to use those methods along with the relationship between slopes of lines to identify and write equations of parallel and perpendicular lines. Students must understand the concept of reciprocals and opposite reciprocals to understand perpendicular lines. Having students compare graphs can help them visualize the concepts.

Students will find the equations of lines parallel and perpendicular to horizontal and vertical lines. They will use the understanding that the slope of a horizontal line is zero and the slope of a vertical line is undefined. 

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:
  • Use the relationship between slopes of lines to write equations of lines that are parallel or perpendicular.
  • Use the point-slope form to write linear equations of parallel and perpendicular lines.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Write an equation of a line parallel to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line.
  • Write an equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to an axis.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)

The parts that are covered have been underlined.
A2(E) write the equation of a line that contains a given point and is parallel to a given line; Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

A3(A) determine the slope of a line given a table of values, a graph, two points on the line, and an equation written in various forms, including \( y = mx + b \), \( Ax + By = C \), and \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \); Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

page.title: 1.13.1: Using Point-Slope Form to Write the Equation of a Line
page.contents:
Warm-Up (5 minutes)

The purpose of this warm-up is to help students recall finding the equation of a line given the slope and a point on the line. The lines are designed to facilitate discussions about lines with the same slope and different \(y\)-intercepts to prepare for work with parallel lines.

Launch

Have students work in pairs. Assign the information for Line A to one of the partners and the information for Line B to the other partner. Give students a couple of minutes to find the slope and equation of the line.

Student-Facing Statement

Your teacher will assign you one pair of the points shown.

Points for Line A: \( (-1, 5) \) and \( (1, 1) \)
Points for Line B: \( (-1, -1) \) and \( (1, -5) \)

Use your assigned points to find the following:

1. Find the slope of the line.
2. Write the equation of the line in slope-intercept form.
3. Compare your equation to your partner’s equation.

Student Response

1. Answers below:

Line A: slope: \( m= \frac{1-5}{1-(-1)}=-2 \)
Line B: slope: \( m= \frac{-5-(-1)}{1-(-1)}=-2 \)

Remember to use the slope formula to find the slope: \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \).

2. Answers below:

Line A: equation \( y = -2x + 3 \)
Line B: equation \( y = -2x - 3 \)

Remember to use the point-slope form for the equation of the line to write the equation: \( y - y_1 = m_1(x - x_1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( y = mx + b \), where the slope is \( m \) and the \( y \)-intercept is \( b \).

3. Sample responses:

  • Both lines have a negative slope.
  • Both lines have the same slope.
  • The \( y \)-intercepts are different.
  • The \( y \)-intercepts have opposite signs.

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may mistakenly find the change in \( x \) over the change in \(y\) when finding the slope. There is a lot of room for error using the point-slope form of the equation of the line. Students may mistakenly substitute the given \( x \)-value for \( y_1 \) and the given \( y \)-value for \( x_1 \). Students may also make errors using the distributive property or may make sign errors when simplifying. Students may think the \( y \)-intercepts are the same because they see the “3” and do not realize in Line B, the 3 is negative.

Activity Synthesis

Ask a few students from each group for their results. Have students share the method they used to write the equation of the line. Then, ask students what they wonder about the results. Students may notice the slopes are the same and the \( y \)-intercepts are different. 

Ask students: 

  • What does the graph of a line with a negative slope look like?
  • What does the graph of a line with a positive slope look like?
  • What does the slope of the line mean on the graph?
  • What do you think two lines with the same slope will look like on the graph?
  • If time allows, have the students graph the lines to see how they compare. This will help introduce the next topic of parallel lines.

page.title: 1.13.2: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel to a Given Line
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

Students will use knowledge of point-slope form to find the equation of lines given a point and a slope. They will then write each equation in slope-intercept form and explore equations with the same slopes and different \(y\)-intercepts. Being exposed to examples and non-examples will help lead them to the concept of parallel lines that have the same slope.

Launch

Allow students to work in pairs to go through each step of the activity. Each student should receive a paper of coordinate grids. Colored pencils and a straight-edge are recommended. When graphing, it is suggested that students graph each line in a different color and label the line with the equation. At the end of the activity, have pairs share their results of each step to the class and what they noticed along the way.

Student-Facing Statement

1. For each of the following slopes and points, find the equation of the line using point-slope form.

a. \( m = 2, (3, 1) \)
b. \( m = 2, (-1, 4) \)
c. \( m = -4, (2, 1) \)
d. \( m = -4, (3, -2) \)

2. Write each of the four equations from the previous question in slope-intercept form.

3. Now, graph the equations \( a \) and \( b \) on one graph and \( c \) and \( d \) on another graph.

4. What is the same in the equations?

5.  What do you notice about the graphs?

6. Here are some examples and non-examples of slopes of lines that are parallel.

Slopes of Parallel Lines
Examples Non-Examples
\( 5, 5 \) \( 5, -5 \)
\( -\frac{1}{7}, -\frac{1}{7} \) \( -7, -\frac{1}{7} \)
\( \frac{4}{9}, \frac{4}{9}\ \) \( \frac{4}{9}, -\frac{4}{9} \)


What do you notice about the pairs of examples of slopes of parallel lines?

7. Now, write an equation of a line that is parallel to \( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \) that goes through \( (9, 2) \).



Student Response

1. Answers below:

a. \( y - 1 = 2(x - 3) \)
b. \( y - 4 = 2(x +1) \)
c. \( y - 1 = -4(x -2) \)
d. \( y +2 = -4(x-3) \)

2. Answers below:

a. \( y = 2x -5 \)
b. \( y = 2x + 6 \)
c. \( y = -4x +9 \)
d. \( y = -4x +10 \)

3. Lines \( a \) and \( b \)

Lines \( c \) and \( d \)




4. The slopes are the same. They are both \( -4 \).

5. The lines have the same slope and will never touch.

6. Parallel lines have the same slope.

7. \( y=\frac{1}{3}x-1 \) is an equation that is parallel to \( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \) and goes through \( (9, 2) \).

First, identify the slope of the line: 

\( m =\frac{1}{3} \)

Next, use the slope and given point \( (9, 2) \) in point-slope form to find the parallel line that goes through the point:

\( y-2=\frac{1}{3}(x-9) \)

Now put the equation in slope-intercept form (solve for \( y \)).

\( y=\frac{1}{3}x-1 \)

1.13.2: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Which equation represents an equation of a line parallel to the line \( y = \frac{1}{2} x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (6, 4) \)?
Answers Feedback
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \)

That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \). 

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). 
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 4 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \). The point on the line is \( (6, 4) \). The first coordinate, \( 6 \), is the \( x \)-coordinate. The second coordinate, \( 4 \), is the \( y \)-coordinate. 

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x - 7 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \).

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). Be sure to add \( 4 \) to both sides of the equation to solve for \( y \). The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x - 2 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the parallel line is the same as the original line, \( \frac{1}{2} \).

Substitute \( \frac{1}{2} \) for \( m \), \( 6 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( 4 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = \frac{1}{2}(x - 6) \). Be sure to distribute \( \frac{1}{2} \) to both terms inside the parentheses to get \( y - 4 =  \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \). 

The answer is \( y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \).


1.13.2: Additional Resources 

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Find the Line Parallel to a Given Line

In this section, you will use what you know about writing the equation of a line given the slope and a point to write the equation of parallel lines. The graph shows the equation of the line \( y = 2x - 3. \) The point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \) is also plotted. You can use the fact that parallel lines have the same slope to find a line that is parallel to line \(m\) and goes through point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \). 



From the equation, you know the slope of the line is 2. The second line will pass through \( (-2, 1) \) and have slope 2. To graph the line, start at \( (-2, 1) \) and count out the rise and run. The slope is \( \frac{rise}{run}=\frac{2}{1} \). Count out the rise, 2, and run, 1, and plot the point. You can graph the line as shown. Line \( m \) is parallel to line \( l \) and goes through point \( P \) \( (-2, 1) \).


To find the equation of a line parallel to a line through a given point algebraically, you can use what you know about finding the equation of a line given the slope and a point.

For example,

Write an equation of a line parallel to \( y = 2x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (-2, 1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Look at the graph with the parallel lines shown previously. Does this equation make sense? What is the \(y\)-intercept of the line? What is the slope?

You can use this table as a reference for writing an equation of a line parallel to a given line. 

Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.
Step 2 Find the slope of the parallel line.
Step 3 Identify the point.
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).
Step 5 Simplify.
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).


Try It: Find the Line Parallel to a Given Line

Write an equation of a line parallel to the line \(y = 3x + 1\) that contains the point \( (4,2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to find a line parallel to a given line and point.

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.  \( m = 3 \)
Step 2 Find the slope of the parallel line.  \( m_1 = 3 \)
Step 3 Identify the point.  \( (x_1, y_1) \)
 \( (4, 4) \)
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).		 \( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \)
\( y-2=3(x-4) \)
Step 5 Simplify.  \( y - 2 = 3x - 12 \)
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form: \( y = mx+b \).  \( y = 3x - 10 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.13.3: Writing an Equation of a Line Perpendicular to a Given Line
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

Students will use knowledge of point-slope form to find the equation of lines given a point and a slope. They will then write each equation in slope-intercept form and explore equations with the same slopes and different \(y\)-intercepts. Being exposed to examples and non-examples will help lead them to the concept of perpendicular lines that have slopes that are opposite reciprocals of each other.

Launch

Allow students to work in pairs to go through each step of the activity. Each student should receive a paper of coordinate grids. Colored pencils and a straight-edge are recommended. When graphing, it is suggested that students graph each line in a different color and label the line with the equation. At the end of the activity, have pairs share their results of each step to the class and what they noticed along the way.

Student-Facing Statement

1. For each of the following slopes and points, find the equation of the line using point-slope form.

a. \( m = 2, (3, 1) \)
b. \( m = -\frac{1}{2}, (-1, 4) \)
c. \( m = -4, (2, 1) \)
d. \( m = \frac{1}{4}, (3, 2) \)

2. Write each of the four equations from the previous question in slope-intercept form.

3. Graph the equations for a and b on one graph and the equations for c and d on another graph.

4. What do you notice about the pairs of lines and their graphs?

5. Complete the table to identify the slope of the line perpendicular to the line whose slope is given.

Slope of Line A Slope of Line B
\( \frac{1}{4} \) A
\( -8 \) B
\( -\frac{6}{11} \) C

6. Now, write the equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = 3x -1 \) that goes through \( (1,2) \).

Student Response

1. Answers:

a.  \( y - 1 = 2(x - 3) \)
b. \( y - 4\ =-\frac{1}{2}(x+1) \)
c. \( y - 1 = -4(x -2) \)
d. \( y-2\ =\frac{1}{4}(x-3) \)

2. Answers:

a. \( y = 2x -5 \)
b. \( y=-\frac{1}{2}x+\frac{7}{2} \)
c. \( y= -4x +9 \)
d. \( y =\frac{1}{4}x+\frac{5}{4} \)

3. Lines \( a \) and \( b \)



Lines \( c \) and \( d \)


4. Sample response:

The lines that have slopes that are opposite signs and reciprocals of each other are perpendicular to each other.

5. Answers:
A. \( -4 \)
B. \( \frac{1}{8} \)
C. \( \frac{11}{6} \)

6. \( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3} \) is an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y = 3x -1 \) and goes through \( (1,2) \).

First, find the slope of the given line: \( m = 3 \).

Next, find the opposite reciprocal of this slope: \( m = - \frac{1}{3} \).

This will be the slope of the perpendicular line. 

Now use this slope, \( m = - \frac{1}{3} \), and the given point, \( (1,2) \), to write an equation of a line with point-slope form: \( y - 2 = -\frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \).

Simplify and write in slope-intercept form: \( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3}+2 \).

\( y= -\frac{1}{3}x+\frac{7}{3} \)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to write an equation of a line that has a slope of zero (students can choose their \(y\)-intercept).

  • \(y = 0x+b\) becomes \(y=b\).
  • What is an equation of a line parallel to \(y=b\)? Can you name a few?
  • What would a line perpendicular to \(y=b\) look like?

This will start to introduce the next concept of finding equations of lines parallel and perpendicular to the axes.

1.13.3: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Which equation represents an equation of a line perpendicular to the line \( y = \frac{1}{2} x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (6, 4) \)? 
Answers Feedback
\( y = -2x + 16  \)

That’s correct! Check yourself: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = –2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \).
\( y = -2x + 14 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). The point on the line is \( (6, 4) \). The first coordinate, 6, is the \( x \)-coordinate. The second coordinate, 4, is the \( y \)-coordinate. 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).
\( y = 2x - 8 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line. Remember to change the sign. The original line has slope \( \frac{1}{2} \). The opposite reciprocal is \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \) to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).
\( y = -2x - 2  \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:

The slope of the perpendicular line is the opposite reciprocal of the slope of the original line, \( -2 \). 

Substitute \( -2 \) for \( m \), 6 for \( x_1 \), and 4 for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - 4 = -2 (x - 6) \). Be sure to distribute \(-2\) to both terms inside the parentheses to get \( y - 4 = -2x + 12 \). 

The answer is \( y = -2x + 16 \).


1.12.3: Additional Resources 

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Finding a Perpendicular Line Given an Equation and Point

In this section, you will use what you know about writing the equation of a line given the slope and a point to write the equation of perpendicular lines. The graph shows the equation of the line \( y = 2x - 3 \). The point \( P(-2, 1) \) is also plotted. You can use the fact that perpendicular lines have slopes that are opposite reciprocals to find a line that is perpendicular to line \(l\) and goes through point \( P(-2, 1) \).


From the equation, you know the slope of the line is 2. The second line will pass through \( P(-2, 1) \) and have slope \( - \frac{1}{2} \). To graph the line, start at \( (-2, 1) \) and count out the rise and run. The slope is \( \frac{rise}{run}=\frac{-1}{2} \). Count out the rise, \( -1 \), and run, 2, and plot the point. You can graph the line as shown. Line \( n \) is perpendicular to line \( l \) and goes through point \( (-2, 1) \).


To find the equation of a line perpendicular to a line through a given point algebraically, you can use what you know about finding the equation of a line given the slope and a point.

For example,

Write an equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = 2x - 3 \) that contains the point \( (-2, 1) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Use this table for reference to write an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line:

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.
Step 2 Find the slope of the perpendicular line.
Step 3 Identify the point.
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).
Step 5 Simplify.
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( (y = mx+b) \).

Try It: Finding a Perpendicular Line Given an Equation and Point

Find an equation of a line perpendicular to the line \( y = 3x + 1 \) that contains the point \( (4, 2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to find a line perpendicular to a given line and point.

Step 1 Find the slope of the given line.  \( m = 3 \)
Step 2 Find the slope of the perpendicular line.   \( m_1 = - \frac{1}{3} \)
Step 3 Identify the point.  \( (x_1, y_1) \)
 \( (4, 2) \)
Step 4 Substitute the values into the point-slope form: 
\( y_2-y_1=m(x_2-x_1) \).		 \( y - y_1 = m_1(x - x_1) \)
\( 2 = -\frac{1}{3} (x - 4) \)
Step 5 Simplify.  \( y - 2 = -\frac{1}{3}x + \frac{4}{3} \)
Step 6 Write the equation in slope-intercept form \( (y = mx+b) \).  \( y = -\frac{1}{3}x + 3\frac{1}{3}  \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.13.4: Writing an Equation of a Line Parallel or Perpendicular to an Axis
page.contents:
Activity (18 minutes)

Students have worked on finding lines that are parallel and perpendicular to other lines that have slopes that are defined and non-zero. In this activity, students will work to find lines that are parallel and perpendicular to the \( x \)- and \( y \)-axes. To do this, students must have an understanding of the coordinate system. They must understand that the \(y\)-axis is vertical and the \(x\)-axis is horizontal. They must also understand that a coordinate is written in the form \( (x, y) \).

Launch

Put students in pairs to work on this activity. Give each student a coordinate grid. A straight-edge and colored pencils would also help students visualize the different types of lines and their relationships.

Student-Facing Statement

The line \( x = 5 \) and the point \( (3, -2) \) are shown on the graph.


Work with a partner to complete the tasks:

1. Identify the slope of the original line, \( l \).

2. Draw a line \( m \) parallel to the given line, \( l \), that goes through the point \( (3, -2) \). 

Then,

a. Identify the slope of the new line, \( m \). 
b. Write the equation of the new line, \( m \).

3. Draw a line \( n \) perpendicular to the given line, \( l \), through the point \( (3, -2) \). 

Then,

a. Identify the slope of the new line, \( n \). 
b. Write the equation of the new line, \( n \).

Student Response

1. Undefined

2. Answers below:


a. Slope: Undefined
b. Equation: \( x = 3 \)

3. Answers below:

a. Slope: 0
b. Equation: \( y = -2 \)

Activity Synthesis

The purpose of the discussion is to elicit conversation about slopes of horizontal lines, vertical lines, parallel lines, and perpendicular lines. Here are some questions for discussion:

  • “How did you find the slope of line \(l\)?” (Vertical lines have undefined slope.)
  • “How does the slope of line \(m\) compare to line \(l\)?” (They are the same because the lines are parallel.)
  • “How does the slope of line \(n\) compare to line \(l\)?” (The slope of line \(n\) is zero because it is a horizontal line. The slope of line \(l\) is undefined because it is a vertical line.)
  • “How do you write the equation of a horizontal line with coordinates \((a, b)\)?” \((y = b)\)
  • “How do you write the equation of a vertical line with coordinates \((a, b)\)?” \((x = a)\)


1.13.3: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Which is the equation of a line that is perpendicular to the line \( x = 1 \) that contains the point \( (-5, 2) \)? 
Answers Feedback
\( y = 2  \) 

That’s correct! Check yourself: The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. 
\( x = -5 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The line you chose is parallel, not perpendicular. The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. The answer is \( y = 2 \).
\( y = 1 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The line you chose does not go through the point \( (-5, 2) \). The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. The answer is \( y = 2 \).
\( y = -2  \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The line you chose does not go through the point \( (-5, 2) \). The given line is vertical and has undefined slope. 

The perpendicular line is horizontal and has slope 0. Every point on the perpendicular line has a \( y \)-coordinate of 2. The answer is \( y = 2 \).


1.13.4: Additional Resources 

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Find Equations of Lines Perpendicular to an Axis

Example 1:

Find an equation of a line perpendicular to \( x=5 \) that contains the point \( (3,-2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Again, since we know one point, the point-slope option seems more promising than the slope-intercept option. We need the slope to use this form, and we know the new line will be perpendicular to \( x=5 \). This line is vertical, so its perpendicular will be horizontal. This tells us the \( m_1=0 \).

Identify the point. \( (3,-2) \)
Identify the slope of the perpendicular line. \( m_1=0 \) 
Substitute the values into \( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \). \( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \)

\( y-(-2)=0(x-3) \)
Simplify. \( y+2=0 \)

\( y=-2 \)

Example 2:

Find an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y=4 \) that contains the point \( (2,3) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

The line \( y=4 \) is a horizontal line. Any line perpendicular to it must be vertical, in the form \( x=a \). Since the perpendicular line is vertical and passes through \( (2,3) \), every point on it has an \(x\)-coordinate of 2. The equation of the perpendicular line is \( x=2 \).

Try It: Find Equations of Lines Perpendicular to an Axis

Find an equation of a line that is perpendicular to \( y = -3 \) that contains the point \( (-3, 5) \).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution 

Here is how to find the equation of a line perpendicular to \( y = -3 \) that contains the point \( (-3, 5) \).

Find the slope of the given line.  The line is horizontal. \( m = 0 \)
Find the slope of the perpendicular line. The perpendicular line is a vertical line. undefined
Identify the point. The given point is \((-3, 5)\).   \( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (-3, 5) \)
Write the equation. The perpendicular line is vertical and passes through \( (-3, 5) \); every point on it has an \(x\)-coordinate of \( -3 \).  \( x = -3 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.13.5: Drawing Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
page.contents:
Cool-Down (5 minutes)

Student-Facing Statement

On the same coordinate grid:

  • Partner A draws a vertical line, and Partner B draws a horizontal line. 
  • Each partner labels their line with its equation in slope-intercept form.

Pass your paper to your partner. 

1. Check your partner’s graph and equation. 

2. Draw a point on your partner’s paper that is not on the line. Label the point \( P \).

3. Draw a line parallel to the original line that goes through point \( P \). Label the line with its equation.

4. Draw a line perpendicular to the original line that goes through point \( P \). Label the line with its equation.
Enter the equation here:

Student Response

1. Partner A’s equation is of the form \( x =\) #, and Partner B’s equation is of the form \( y =\) #. 

2. Point \( P \) shouldn’t be on the partner’s initial line. 

3. The equation of your line will depend on where you drew it on the coordinate grid, but it should have the same slope (0 or undefined) as the first equation.

4. The equation of your line will depend on where you drew it on the coordinate grid, but it should have a slope that is not the same as the first equation.

Activity Synthesis

The purpose of the discussion is to elicit conversation about equations of lines parallel or perpendicular to horizontal or vertical lines.

  • “What do you notice about the equations of vertical lines?” (They are of the form \( x = a \).)
  • “What do you notice about the equations of lines perpendicular to vertical lines?” (They are of the form \( y = b \).)
  • “What do you notice about the equations of horizontal lines?” (They are of the form \( y = b \).)
  • “What do you notice about the equations of lines perpendicular to horizontal lines?” (They are of the form \( x = a \).)

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool-down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool-down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 1.13.6: Practice
page.contents:

In questions 1–5, find an equation of a line that is parallel to the given line and contains the given point. Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

page.title: 1.13.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
The key takeaways of this lesson are that parallel lines have the same slope while perpendicular lines have slopes that are opposite reciprocals of each other. Students should be able to identify the slope of a line from a graph or equation. Then, they should be able to use it along with another point to write the equation of a parallel or perpendicular line.

Students should also be able to write lines that are parallel or perpendicular to the \( x \)-axis and \( y \)-axis and understand that the equations are written as \( y \) = # or \( x \) = #, respectively.

Visual learners can benefit from graphing lines throughout the lesson by hand or via graphing technology so that they can see the slopes of the lines as well as the \( y \)-intercepts.

To continue to the student-facing version of this lesson, select “Lesson 1.13: Writing Equations of Parallel and Perpendicular Lines” below.
